data.title: Radio Stations
data.meta_description: The game supports two built-in radio modes: Playback of local MP3/OGG files on your PC, or streaming. American Truck Simulator and Euro Truck Simulator 2 both support streaming radio stations in http/mp3 and mms formats. You can manually add internet radio streams to the game by adding the...
data.text:
Important Notice The list(s) below this article lists every possible radio station that can be streamed via Euro Truck Simulator 2 and American Truck Simulator from the internet.

Because of that, this article has been updated frequently due to radio station becoming outdated, replaced, dead, or the lexicon is incomplete. Please, do not hesitate to edit / correct any information in this article. We thank you for your help contribution to the Truck Simulator Wiki.

The game supports two built-in radio modes: Playback of local MP3/OGG files on your PC, or streaming.

Editing live_streams.sii file manually[]

American Truck Simulator and Euro Truck Simulator 2 both support streaming radio stations in http/mp3 and mms formats. You can manually add internet radio streams to the game by adding the stream URL to a config file. To do this:

Load ETS2 or ATS at least once, and navigate to Radio -> Streaming -> Update From Internet

Open My Documents\Euro Truck Simulator 2\live_streams.sii in Notepad

Scroll to the bottom of the list and add in new stations in the same format as the ones above

Make sure the stream numbers are unique for each line (stream_data[XX], where as XX are supposed to be unique, sequential numbers for every station. i.e. 1,2,3,4...,70,71,72)

Note: You can overwrite pre-existing streams with your custom ones, then use 'Update From Internet' within the game without overwriting your custom streams.

Begin with the next numerical order value of the stream data number. Follow with the URL of the stream, the name of the station, the genre, the language (maximum 3 characters), the bitrate and a 0 or 1 value for favorites. All values should be separated by a vertical bar (|) and not include a space in between values.

(replace brackets with values) stream_data[(next stream number)]: "(stream link)|(stream name)|(genre)|(two letter language code)|(bitrate)|(favorite 0 or 1)"

Note that the stream link does not need the port bit set, i.e. the 8000, 8010 or similar numbers preceded by a colon that you see on many links in the live_streams.sii file.

The final entry should look close to this:

stream_data[232]: "http://217.74.72.10:8000/rmf_60s|Radio|Genre|PL|128|1"

☀https://youtu.be/zAmltJ27CHU?si=ZeSrv4-h9by-WyTj

If you've already performed "Update from Internet", you may replace the values downloaded, following the example.

Dead Streams[]

Graphical alternative[]

You can use the open-source tool ETS Radio Manager, which allows you to edit the live_streams.sii file through a graphical interface. fmstream.org is a great source for stations & getting Bitrate, Local & genre information.
